</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Revenues from our environmental fee contributed $72&nbsp;million and $17&nbsp;million for the years ended
	December 31, 2016 and 2015, respectively, to our collection and disposal average yield.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Recycling commodities
</I>
	&#151; Our revenues
	increased $51&nbsp;million for the year ended December 31, 2016 as compared with the prior year period due to a 7%
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	year-over-year
</FONT>
</FONT>
	increase in the market prices for the
	recycling commodities we sell at our recycling facilities and through our recycling brokerage services. During 2015, revenues declined by $138&nbsp;million as compared with the prior year due to a 12%
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	year-over-year
</FONT>
	decline in recycling commodities prices.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Fuel surcharges and mandated fees
	&#151;
</I>
	These revenues, which are predominantly generated by our fuel surcharge program, decreased $67&nbsp;million and $171&nbsp;million for the years ended December 31, 2016 and 2015, respectively. These revenues fluctuate in response to
	changes in the national average prices for diesel fuel on which our surcharge is based. Market prices for diesel fuel decreased approximately 14% in 2016 and 30% in 2015, which caused the decline in fuel surcharge revenues in 2016 and 2015. The
	mandated fees included in this line item are primarily related to pass-through fees and taxes assessed by various state, county and municipal government agencies at our landfills and transfer stations. These fees did not have a significant impact on
	the comparability of the periods presented.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	44
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage45"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D252547D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D252547D10K_HTM_INDEX">
	Index to Financial Statements
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Volume
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Our revenues increased $186&nbsp;million, or 1.4%, for the year ended December 31, 2016 as compared with the prior year due to higher volumes.
	The year-over-year comparison does not include volumes from acquisitions, as discussed below. We experienced higher volumes in all of our collection and disposal lines of business, with the exception of our residential line of business, as a result
	of (i) improving market conditions; (ii)&nbsp;reduced customer churn and improved sales performance supported by our focus on disciplined growth and (iii)&nbsp;an additional workday in 2016.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Additional drivers affecting the comparability of volumes for 2016 to 2015 are as follows:
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	Due to our focus on renegotiating existing contracts and winning new contracts with reasonable returns, we continue to see revenue declines in our residential line of business; and
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	In our ancillary service businesses, we experienced higher volumes in 2016 as compared with the prior year resulting from our Energy and Environmental Services organization, particularly our remediation and construction
	services, WM Renewable Energy and our portable
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	self-storage
</FONT>
	businesses. These volume increases were partially offset by lower volumes resulting from lower oil prices, which negatively affected both our oil and
	gas producing properties and our oilfield services business.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Declines in our volumes caused our revenue to decrease
	$215&nbsp;million, or 1.6%, for the year ended December 31, 2015, as compared with the prior year. We experienced lower volumes in (i)&nbsp;our collection line of business, primarily due to competition and our pricing strategies; (ii)&nbsp;our MRFs,
	primarily driven by the rationalization of our underperforming assets and our strategy to not renew municipal contracts that did not reflect current market conditions and (iii)&nbsp;our ancillary services businesses, primarily due to the loss of
	certain large accounts in our WMSBS organization and lower oil prices, which negatively affected both our oil and gas producing properties and our oilfield services business. These decreases in volumes were partially offset by increases in the
	municipal solid waste business driven by new business and improving market&nbsp;conditions that favorably affected our landfill and transfer lines of business.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Acquisitions and divestitures
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Revenues increased $268&nbsp;million and $174&nbsp;million for the years ended December 31, 2016 and 2015, respectively, as compared with the
	prior year periods, due to acquisitions. The increase in revenues in 2016 was principally due to the acquired operations of SWS in January 2016. The revenue increase in 2015 was principally due to the acquired operations of Deffenbaugh in March
	2015.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	These revenues were offset by revenue decreases of $30&nbsp;million and $762&nbsp;million for the years ended December 31, 2016 and
	2015, respectively, as compared with the prior year periods, due to divestitures. The decrease in revenues in 2015 was primarily driven by the divestitures in 2014 of our Wheelabrator business, our Puerto Rico operations and certain landfill and
	collection operations in our Eastern Canada Area.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Operating Expenses
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Our operating expenses are comprised of (i)&nbsp;labor and related benefits (excluding labor costs associated with maintenance and repairs
	discussed below), which include salaries and wages, bonuses, related payroll taxes, insurance and benefits costs and the costs associated with contract labor; (ii)&nbsp;transfer and disposal costs, which include tipping fees paid to third-party
	disposal facilities and transfer stations; (iii)&nbsp;maintenance and repairs relating to equipment, vehicles and facilities and related labor costs; (iv)&nbsp;subcontractor costs, which include the costs of independent haulers who transport waste
	collected by us to disposal facilities and are affected by variables such as volumes, distance and fuel prices; (v)&nbsp;costs of goods sold, which includes the cost to purchase recycling materials for our recycling business, including rebates paid
	to suppliers; (vi)&nbsp;fuel costs, which represent the costs of fuel and oil to operate our truck fleet and landfill operating equipment; (vii)&nbsp;disposal and franchise fees and taxes, which include landfill taxes, municipal franchise fees, host
	community fees, contingent landfill
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	45
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage46"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D252547D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D252547D10K_HTM_INDEX">
	Index to Financial Statements
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	lease payments and royalties; (viii)&nbsp;landfill operating costs, which include interest accretion on landfill liabilities, interest accretion on and discount rate adjustments to environmental
	remediation liabilities and recovery assets, leachate and methane collection and treatment, landfill remediation costs and other landfill site costs; (ix)&nbsp;risk management costs, which include general liability, automobile liability,
	workers&#146; compensation and insurance and claim costs and (x)&nbsp;other operating costs, which include telecommunications, equipment and facility rent, property taxes, utilities and supplies.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Our operating expenses increased $255&nbsp;million, or 3.1%, when comparing 2016 with 2015 and decreased $771&nbsp;million, or 8.6%, when
	comparing 2015 with 2014. Operating expenses as a percentage of revenues were 62.4% in 2016, 63.5% in 2015, and 64.3% in 2014.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Significant items affecting the comparison of operating expenses between periods reported include:
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Labor and related benefits
</I>
	&#151; The increase in labor and related benefits in 2016 as compared with 2015 was due to (i)&nbsp;higher
	wages due to merit increases; (ii)&nbsp;additional costs associated with the acquired operations of SWS in January 2016; (iii) health and welfare cost increases; (iv)&nbsp;an additional workday in 2016 and (v)&nbsp;higher incentive compensation
	costs. These cost increases were partially offset by (i) $51&nbsp;million of charges in 2015 associated with the withdrawal from certain underfunded Multiemployer Pension Plans and (ii)&nbsp;lower headcount and contract labor costs in 2016 due to
	operating efficiencies in our recycling line of business.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The decrease in labor and related benefits in 2015 as compared with 2014 was
	due to (i)&nbsp;reduced costs of $88&nbsp;million due to the divestitures in 2014 of our Wheelabrator business, our Puerto Rico operations, and certain landfill and collection operations in our Eastern Canada Area; (ii)&nbsp;lower headcount and
	contract labor costs due to operating efficiencies in our recycling line of business and lower volumes in our collection line of business and (iii)&nbsp;lower health and welfare costs. These cost decreases were partially offset by (i)
	$51&nbsp;million of charges in 2015 associated with the withdrawal from certain underfunded Multiemployer Pension Plans; (ii)&nbsp;higher wages due to merit increases and (iii)&nbsp;additional costs associated with the acquired operations of
	Deffenbaugh in March 2015.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Transfer and disposal costs &#151;
</I>
	The increase in transfer and disposal costs in 2016 compared to 2015
	was driven by acquisitions, primarily SWS, and our overall increase in volumes. The increase in costs in 2015 compared to 2014 was primarily due to incurring third-party costs for services previously provided on an intercompany basis prior to the
	divestiture of our Wheelabrator business in December 2014. These cost increases were partially offset by $53&nbsp;million in reduced costs due to the divestitures in 2014.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	46
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage47"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D252547D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D252547D10K_HTM_INDEX">
	Index to Financial Statements
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Maintenance and repairs
</I>
	&#151; The increase in maintenance and repairs in 2016 compared to
	2015 was primarily driven by (i)&nbsp;higher labor and parts and supplies costs and (ii)&nbsp;acquisitions, primarily the acquired operations of SWS. The decrease in costs in 2015 compared to 2014 was largely driven by a $177&nbsp;million decrease
	due to the divestitures in 2014, which was partially offset by increased costs related to the acquired operations of Deffenbaugh.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Subcontractor costs
</I>
	&#151; The increase in subcontractor cost in 2016 compared to 2015 was driven by (i)&nbsp;acquisitions and
	(ii)&nbsp;higher volumes in our WMSBS organization. These increases were partially offset by a decrease in subcontracted remediation services to industrial customers. The decrease in costs in 2015 compared to 2014 was primarily driven by
	(i)&nbsp;volume decreases in our WMSBS organization and (ii)&nbsp;lower landfill and recycling costs. These decreases were partially offset by an increase in subcontracted remediation services to industrial customers.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Cost of goods sold &#151;
</I>
	The increase in cost of goods sold in 2016 compared to 2015 was due to (i)&nbsp;higher market prices for
	recycling commodities and (ii)&nbsp;increased costs in our remediation services business, partially offset by lower costs due to continued efforts to restructure recycling rebates paid to customers. The decrease in costs in 2015 compared to 2014 was
	due to (i)&nbsp;lower market prices for recycling commodities; (ii)&nbsp;lower costs of $81&nbsp;million due to the 2014 divestitures; (iii)&nbsp;increased efforts to restructure recycling rebates paid to customers and (iv)&nbsp;ongoing recycling
	business improvement efforts around inbound quality control.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Fuel &#151;
</I>
	The decrease in fuel costs in 2016 and 2015 when compared
	to the prior year periods was driven by (i)&nbsp;lower fuel prices; (ii)&nbsp;lower costs resulting from the continued conversion of our fleet to natural gas vehicles;
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	(iii)&nbsp;year-over-year
</FONT>
</FONT>
	increases in natural gas fuel excise credits and (iv)&nbsp;reduced fuel consumption due to efficiency gains in the routing of our fleet. The
	increase in collection volumes in 2016 partially offset these decreases.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Disposal and franchise fees and taxes &#151;
</I>
	The increase
	in disposal and franchise fees and taxes in 2016 compared to 2015 is primarily due to (i)&nbsp;higher landfill volumes and (ii)&nbsp;increased municipal franchise fees and subcontracted remediation services to industrial customers. The decrease when
	comparing 2015 to 2014 is primarily driven by the divestitures in 2014.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Landfill operating costs &#151;
</I>
	The increase in landfill
	operating costs when comparing 2016 to 2015 is primarily due to higher leachate management costs. Leachate management costs have increased because, in certain parts of the country, we are transporting leachate further in order to reach treatment
	facilities, the third-party fees charged for treatment of waste water have increased and the volume of leachate being disposed has increased.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Higher leachate transportation and disposal costs also affected the comparison of our landfill operating costs for 2015 and 2014, though the
	increased costs were more than offset by the impact of 2014 divestitures and discount rate adjustments. As discussed in Note 3 to the Consolidated Financial Statements, we record adjustments to our landfill operating costs for changes in U.S.
	Treasury rates used to discount the present value of our environmental remediation liabilities and recovery assets.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Risk management
	&#151;
</I>
	The decrease in costs in 2016 compared to 2015 was primarily due to a reduction in certain uninsured losses and, to a lesser extent, decreased workers&#146; compensation claims.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Other &#151;
</I>
	The decrease in costs in 2016 compared to 2015 was primarily related to lower rental costs and favorable adjustments to
	our contingent consideration liabilities associated with certain acquisitions. The decrease in costs in 2015 compared to 2014 was principally driven by a decrease of $63&nbsp;million due to the divestitures in 2014.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Selling, General and Administrative Expenses
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Our selling, general and administrative expenses consist of (i)&nbsp;labor and related benefits which include salaries, bonuses, related
	insurance and benefits, contract labor, payroll taxes and equity-based compensation;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	47
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage48"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D252547D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D252547D10K_HTM_INDEX">
	Index to Financial Statements
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	(ii)&nbsp;professional fees, which include fees for consulting, legal, audit and tax services; (iii)&nbsp;provision for bad debts, which includes allowances for uncollectible customer accounts
	and collection fees and (iv)&nbsp;other selling, general and administrative expenses, which include, among other costs,
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	facility-related
</FONT>
	expenses, voice and data telecommunication, advertising, bank charges,
	computer costs, travel and entertainment, rentals, postage and printing. In addition, the financial impacts of litigation settlements generally are included in our &#147;Other&#148; selling, general and administrative expenses.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Our selling, general and administrative expenses increased $67&nbsp;million, or 5.0%, when comparing 2016 with 2015 and decreased
	$138&nbsp;million, or 9.3%, when comparing 2015 with 2014. Our selling, general and administrative expenses as a percentage of revenues were 10.4% in 2016, 10.4% in 2015 and 10.6% in 2014.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The following table summarizes the major components of our selling, general and administrative expenses for the years ended December 31
	(dollars in millions):
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>

</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Significant factors affecting our expense in 2016 as compared to 2015 include:
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Labor and related benefits
</I>
	&#151; The increase in labor and related benefits was primarily due to (i)&nbsp;higher incentive
	compensation costs; (ii)&nbsp;merit increases; (iii)&nbsp;higher severance costs and (iv)&nbsp;acquisitions.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Professional fees
</I>
	&#151; The decrease in professional fees was primarily due to lower legal fees.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Other
</I>
	&#151; The decrease in other expenses
	was principally driven by favorable litigation settlements and lower bank charges.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The divestitures in 2014, primarily the sale of our
	Wheelabrator business in December 2014, favorably affected all cost categories when comparing expenses in 2015 to 2014. In addition to the impact of divestitures, other significant factors affecting our expense in 2015 as compared to 2014 include:
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Labor and related benefits
</I>
	&#151; The decrease in labor and related benefits was due to (i)&nbsp;cost savings from our August 2014
	reorganization and (ii)&nbsp;lower incentive compensation costs, which were partially offset by merit increases.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Other
</I>
	&#151; The
	decrease in other expenses was principally driven by lower litigation settlement costs and our continued focus on controlling costs.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Depreciation and Amortization Expenses
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Depreciation and amortization expenses include (i)&nbsp;depreciation of property and equipment, including assets recorded for capital leases,
	on a
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	straight-line
</FONT>
	basis from three to 40 years; (ii)&nbsp;amortization of landfill costs, including those incurred and all estimated future costs for landfill development, construction and asset retirement
	costs arising from closure and post-closure, on a
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	units-of-consumption
</FONT>
</FONT>
	method as landfill airspace is consumed over the total estimated remaining capacity of a site,
	which includes both permitted capacity and expansion capacity that meets our
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Company-specific
</FONT>
	criteria for amortization purposes; (iii)&nbsp;amortization of landfill asset retirement costs arising from final
	capping obligations on a units-of-consumption method as airspace is
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	48
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage49"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D252547D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D252547D10K_HTM_INDEX">
	Index to Financial Statements
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	consumed over the estimated capacity associated with each final capping event and (iv)&nbsp;amortization of intangible assets with a definite life, using either a 150% declining balance approach
	or a straight-line basis over the definitive terms of the related agreements, which are generally from two to 15 years depending on the type of asset.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The following table summarizes the components of our depreciation and amortization expenses for the years ended December 31 (dollars in
	millions):
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>

</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The increase in depreciation of tangible property and equipment and amortization of intangible assets during
	2016 as compared to the prior year is primarily due to the acquired operations of SWS in January 2016. The increase in amortization of landfill airspace during 2016 as compared to the prior year is due to increased volumes at our landfills,
	partially offset by changes in our landfill estimates.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The decrease in depreciation of tangible property and equipment during 2015 as
	compared to the prior year is primarily due to the December 2014 sale of our Wheelabrator business as discussed further in Note 19 to the Consolidated Financial Statements. The increase in amortization of landfill airspace during 2015 as compared to
	the prior year is primarily due to increased volumes, a portion of which relates to the acquisition of Deffenbaugh in March 2015. This increase was partially offset by favorable adjustments resulting from changes in landfill estimates.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Restructuring Costs
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	During the year ended December 31, 2016, we recognized $4&nbsp;million of pre-tax restructuring charges, of which $2&nbsp;million was related
	to employee severance and benefit costs. The remaining charges were primarily related to operating lease obligations for property that will no longer be utilized.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	During the year ended December 31, 2015, we recognized $15&nbsp;million of pre-tax restructuring charges, of which $10&nbsp;million was
	related to employee severance and benefit costs, including costs associated with the loss of a municipal contract in our Eastern Canada Area and our acquisition of Deffenbaugh. The remaining charges were primarily related to operating lease
	obligations for property that will no longer be utilized.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In August 2014, we announced a consolidation and realignment of several
	Corporate functions to better support achievement of the Company&#146;s strategic goals, including cost reduction. Voluntary separation arrangements were offered to all salaried employees within these organizations. Approximately 650 employees
	separated from our Corporate and recycling organizations in connection with this restructuring. During the year ended December 31, 2014, we recognized a total of $82&nbsp;million of pre-tax restructuring charges, of which $70&nbsp;million was
	related to employee severance and benefit costs. The remaining charges were primarily related to operating lease obligations for property that will no longer be utilized.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	49
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage50"></A>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	During the year ended December 31, 2016, we recognized net charges of $112&nbsp;million, primarily related to
	(i) $44&nbsp;million of charges to adjust our subsidiary&#146;s estimated environmental remediation liability related to a closed site in Harris County, Texas, as further discussed in Note 11 to the Consolidated Financial Statements; (ii)&nbsp;a
	$43&nbsp;million charge to impair a landfill in Western Pennsylvania due to a loss of expected volumes; (iii) $12&nbsp;million of goodwill impairment charges primarily related to our
	LampTracker
<SUP STYLE="FONT-SIZE:85%; VERTICAL-ALIGN:TOP">
	&reg;
</SUP>
	reporting unit and (iv)&nbsp;an $8&nbsp;million loss on the sale of a
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	majority-owned
</FONT>
	organics company.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	During the year ended December 31, 2015, we recognized net charges of $82&nbsp;million, primarily related to (i) $66&nbsp;million of charges
	to impair certain of our oil and gas producing properties as a result of the continued decline in oil and gas prices; (ii) $18&nbsp;million of charges to write down or divest certain assets in our recycling operations and (iii)&nbsp;a
	$5&nbsp;million impairment of a landfill in our Western Canada Area due to revised
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	post-closure
</FONT>
	cost estimates. Partially offsetting these charges was $7&nbsp;million in net gains from divestitures, including
	a $6&nbsp;million gain on the sale of an oil and gas producing property in 2015.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	During the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014, we
	recognized net gains of $160&nbsp;million, primarily related to the following:
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<I>
	Divestitures
</I>
	&#151; We recognized net gains of $515&nbsp;million, primarily as a result of a $519&nbsp;million gain on the sale of our Wheelabrator business and an $18&nbsp;million gain on the sale of certain
	landfill and collection operations in our Eastern Canada Area. Partially offsetting these gains was a $25&nbsp;million loss on the divestiture of our Puerto Rico operations. Refer to Note 19 to the Consolidated Financial Statements for additional
	information related to our divestitures.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<I>
	Oil and gas producing properties impairments
</I>
	&#151; We recognized $272&nbsp;million of charges to impair certain of our oil and gas producing properties, primarily as a result of the pronounced decrease in oil
	and gas prices in the fourth quarter of 2014.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">

</TD>

	Goodwill impairments
</I>

</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>

</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	See Note 3 to the Consolidated Financial Statements for additional information related to the accounting policy and
	analysis involved in identifying and calculating impairments.
</P>

<I>
	Solid Waste &#151;
</I>
	The most significant items affecting the results
	of operations of our Solid Waste business during the three years ended December 31, 2016 are summarized below:
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	Our Traditional Solid Waste business benefited from internal revenue growth; and
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">

	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	We recognized $51&nbsp;million of charges associated with the withdrawal from certain underfunded Multiemployer Pension Plans in 2015 impacting all three tiers.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">

	&nbsp;

<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">

	&#149;

<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	Our recycling business was favorable in 2016 compared to 2015 principally due to (i)&nbsp;continued cost reductions; (ii)&nbsp;higher market prices for recycling commodities and (iii)&nbsp;the impairment of various
	recycling assets in 2015;
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Other
</I>
	&#151; Our &#147;Other&#148; income from operations includes (i)&nbsp;our WMSBS
	organization; (ii)&nbsp;those elements of our landfill
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	gas-to-energy
</FONT>
</FONT>
	operations and third-party subcontract and administration revenues managed by our Energy and
	Environmental Services and WM Renewable Energy organizations that are not included with the operations of our reportable segments; (iii)&nbsp;our recycling brokerage services and (iv)&nbsp;our expanded service offerings and solutions, such as
	portable
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	self-storage
</FONT>
	and long distance moving services, fluorescent lamp recycling, and interests we hold in oil and gas producing properties. In addition, our &#147;Other&#148; income from operations
	reflects the results of
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-operating
</FONT>
	entities that provide financial assurance and
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	self-insurance
</FONT>
	support for our Solid Waste business.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The following items affected comparability of 2016 to 2015:
</P>

	&nbsp;

	&nbsp;

</TD>

	An increase in a subsidiary&#146;s estimated environmental remediation liability related to a closed site in Harris County, Texas in 2016;
</TD>
</TR>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Wheelabrator &#151;
</I>
	The most significant item affecting the results of operations of our Wheelabrator business in 2014 was a
	$519&nbsp;million gain on sale of this business in December 2014.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Interest Expense, net
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Our interest expense, net was $376&nbsp;million in 2016, $385&nbsp;million in 2015 and $466&nbsp;million in 2014. During 2016, the decrease in
	interest expense was primarily attributable to the impacts of lower market interest rates on certain of our tax-exempt bonds, partially offset by increased borrowings under our $2.25&nbsp;billion revolving credit facility. During 2015, the decrease
	in interest expense was primarily attributable to the refinancing of a significant portion of our high-coupon senior notes. As a result of the combination of make-whole redemptions of certain senior notes, cash tender offers to purchase certain
	senior notes and the issuance of $1.8&nbsp;billion of new senior notes, we reduced the weighted average interest rate of our senior note portfolio by 1%.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Loss on Early Extinguishment of Debt
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Loss on early extinguishment of debt was $4&nbsp;million and $555&nbsp;million in 2016 and 2015, respectively. The amount for 2015 was
	primarily associated with the early extinguishment of almost $2&nbsp;billion of our high-coupon senior notes through
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	make-whole
</FONT>
	redemption and cash tender offers. We replaced substantially all of the debt
	extinguished with new senior notes at significantly lower coupon interest rates and extended the weighted average duration of these debt obligations. The &#147;Loss on early extinguishment of debt&#148; reflected in our Consolidated Statement of
	Operations for 2015 includes $122&nbsp;million of charges related to
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	make-whole
</FONT>
	redemptions and $430&nbsp;million of charges related to cash tender offers.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Equity in Net Losses of Unconsolidated Entities
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	We recognized equity in net losses of unconsolidated entities of $44&nbsp;million, $38&nbsp;million and $53&nbsp;million in 2016, 2015 and
	2014, respectively. These losses are primarily related to our noncontrolling interests in entities established to invest in and manage
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	low-income
</FONT>
	housing properties and a refined coal facility. The tax impacts
	realized as a result of our investments in
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	low-income
</FONT>
	housing properties and the refined coal facility are discussed below in
<I>
	Provision for Income Taxes.
</I>
	Refer to Notes 9 and 20 to the Consolidated
	Financial Statements for more information related to these investments. The amount in 2014 includes charges of $11&nbsp;million primarily to write down equity method investments in waste diversion technology companies to their fair value.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Other, net
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	We
	recognized other, net expense of $50&nbsp;million, $7&nbsp;million and $29&nbsp;million in 2016, 2015 and 2014, respectively. The expenses for 2016, 2015 and 2014 were impacted by impairment charges of $42&nbsp;million, $5&nbsp;million and
	$22&nbsp;million, respectively, related to
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	other-than-temporary
</FONT>
</FONT>
	declines in the value of minority-owned, cost method investments in waste diversion technology companies.
	In addition, we recognized $8&nbsp;million of expense during the first quarter of 2016 associated with the termination of our
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	cross-currency
</FONT>
	swaps, which is discussed further in Note 8 to the Consolidated
	Financial Statements.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Provision for Income Taxes
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	We recorded provisions for income taxes of $642&nbsp;million, $308&nbsp;million and $413&nbsp;million in 2016, 2015 and 2014, respectively.
	These tax provisions resulted in effective income tax rates of 35.2%, 29.1% and 23.6% for the
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	53

	years ended 2016, 2015 and 2014, respectively. The comparability of our reported income taxes for the years ended December 31, 2016, 2015 and 2014 is primarily affected by (i)&nbsp;variations in
	our income before income taxes, as discussed above; (ii)&nbsp;federal tax credits; (iii)&nbsp;tax audit settlements; (iv)&nbsp;the realization of state net operating losses and credits; (v)&nbsp;adjustments to our accruals and related deferred taxes
	and (vi)&nbsp;the tax implications of impairments and divestitures. The impacts of these items are summarized below:

	&#151; Our
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	low-income
</FONT>
	housing properties and refined coal facility investments reduced our provision for income taxes
	by $55&nbsp;million, $57&nbsp;million and $58&nbsp;million, primarily as a result of the tax credits realized from these investments for the years ended December 31, 2016, 2015 and 2014, respectively. Refer to Note 9 to the Consolidated Financial

	Adjustments to Accruals and Related Deferred Taxes
</I>
	&#150; Adjustments to our accruals and related deferred taxes due to the filing of our income tax returns and changes in state laws resulted in a
	reduction of $10&nbsp;million, $18&nbsp;million and $24&nbsp;million to our provision for income taxes for the years ended December 31, 2016, 2015 and 2014, respectively.

<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;

<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">

<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<I>
	Tax Implications of Impairments
</I>
	&#151; A portion of the impairment charges recognized in 2016, 2015 and 2014 are not deductible for tax purposes. Had the charges been fully deductible, our provision for income
	taxes would have been reduced by $15&nbsp;million, $2&nbsp;million and $8&nbsp;million for the years ended December 31, 2016, 2015 and 2014, respectively. See Note 13 to the Consolidated Financial Statements for more information related to our
	impairment charges.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<I>
	Tax Implications of Divestitures
</I>
	&#151; During 2014, the Company recorded a net gain of $515&nbsp;million primarily related to the divestiture of our Wheelabrator business, our Puerto Rico operations and certain
	landfill and collection operations in our Eastern Canada Area. Had this net gain been fully taxable, our provision for income taxes would have increased by $138&nbsp;million. During 2015, the Company recorded an additional $10&nbsp;million net gain
	primarily related to
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	post-closing
</FONT>
	adjustments on the Wheelabrator divestiture and had this gain been fully taxable, our provision for income taxes would have increased by $4&nbsp;million. During 2016, the
	Company recorded a loss of $9&nbsp;million related to the divestiture of certain assets and had the associated tax loss been fully deductible, our provision for income taxes would have decreased by $5&nbsp;million. Refer to Note 19 to the
	Consolidated Financial Statements for more information related to our divestitures.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Based on current tax laws and
	regulations, we expect our 2017 recurring effective tax rate will be approximately 36.5% based on projected income before income taxes, federal tax credits and other permanent items.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Noncontrolling Interests
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Net loss attributable to noncontrolling interests was $2&nbsp;million in 2016 and $1&nbsp;million in 2015 and net income attributable to
	noncontrolling interests was $40&nbsp;million in 2014. The income for 2014 was principally related to third-parties&#146; equity interests in two limited liability companies (&#147;LLCs&#148;) that owned three
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	waste-to-
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">

	Index to Financial Statements
</A>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	energy facilities operated by our Wheelabrator business. In December 2014, we purchased the noncontrolling interests in the LLCs from the third parties. The LLCs were then subsequently sold as
	part of the divestiture of our Wheelabrator business. Refer to Notes 19 and 20 to the Consolidated Financial Statements for information related to the sale of our Wheelabrator business and the consolidation of these variable interest entities,
	respectively.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Landfill and Environmental Remediation Discussion and Analysis
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	We owned or operated 243 solid waste and five secure hazardous waste landfills at December 31, 2016 and 244 solid waste and five secure
	hazardous waste landfills at December 31, 2015. For these landfills, the following table reflects changes in capacity, as measured in tons of waste, for the years ended December 31 and remaining capacity, measured in cubic yards of waste, at
	December 31 (in millions):
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>

<P STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:8.0PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:2PT;BORDER-BOTTOM:1PX SOLID #000000;WIDTH:10%">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	(a)
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	Amounts reflected here relate to the combined impacts of (i)&nbsp;new expansions pursued; (ii)&nbsp;increases or decreases in the airspace being pursued for ongoing expansion efforts; (iii)&nbsp;adjustments for
	differences between the airspace being pursued and airspace granted and (iv)&nbsp;decreases due to decisions to no longer pursue expansion permits, if any.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	(b)
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	We received expansion permits at 13 of our landfills during 2016 and six of our landfills during 2015, demonstrating our continued success in working with municipalities and regulatory agencies to expand the disposal
	capacity of our existing landfills.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	(c)
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	Changes in engineering estimates can result in changes to the estimated available remaining capacity of a landfill or changes in the utilization of such landfill capacity, affecting the number of tons that can be placed
	in the future. Estimates of the amount of waste that can be placed in the future are reviewed annually by our engineers and are based on a number of factors, including standard engineering techniques and
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	site-specific
</FONT>
	factors such as current and projected mix of waste type; initial and projected waste density; estimated number of years of life remaining; depth of underlying waste; anticipated access to
	moisture through precipitation or recirculation of landfill leachate and operating practices. We continually focus on improving the utilization of airspace through efforts that include recirculating landfill leachate where allowed by permit;
	optimizing the placement of daily cover materials and increasing initial compaction through improved landfill equipment, operations and training.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	55
</P>

	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	(a)
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	In 2016, we developed one landfill, our contract expired at one landfill and we closed one landfill.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	(b)
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	These amounts include 1.2&nbsp;million tons at both December 31, 2016 and 2015, that were received at our landfills but were used for beneficial purposes and generally were redirected from the permitted airspace to
	other areas of the landfill. Waste types that are frequently identified for beneficial use include green waste for composting and clean dirt for on-site construction projects.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	When a landfill we own or operate receives certification of closure from the applicable regulatory agency, we generally transfer the
	management of the site, including any remediation activities, to our closed sites management group. As of December&nbsp;31, 2016, our closed sites management group managed 213 closed landfills.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Based on remaining permitted airspace as of December 31, 2016 and projected annual disposal volumes, the weighted average remaining landfill
	life for all of our owned or operated landfills is approximately 45 years. Many of our landfills have the potential for expanded disposal capacity beyond what is currently permitted. We monitor the availability of permitted disposal capacity at each
	of our landfills and evaluate whether to pursue an expansion at a given landfill based on estimated future waste volumes, disposal prices, construction and operating costs, remaining capacity and likelihood of obtaining an expansion permit. We are
	seeking expansion permits at 16 of our landfills that meet the expansion criteria outlined in the
<I>
	Critical Accounting Estimates and Assumptions &#151; Landfills
</I>
	section above. Although no assurances can be made that all future expansions will
	be permitted or permitted as designed, the weighted average remaining landfill life for all owned or operated landfills is approximately 47 years when considering remaining permitted airspace, expansion airspace and projected annual disposal volume.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The number of landfills owned or operated as of December 31, 2016, segregated by their estimated operating lives based on remaining
	permitted and expansion capacity and projected annual disposal volume, was as follows:
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>

<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	(a)
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	Of the 248 landfills, 200 are owned, 35 are operated under lease agreements and the remaining 13 are operated under other contractual agreements. We are usually responsible for the final capping, closure and
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	post-closure
</FONT>
	obligations of these landfills.
</TD>
</TR>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	56
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage57"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D252547D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D252547D10K_HTM_INDEX">
	Index to Financial Statements
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	As of December 31, 2016, we have 15 landfills which are not currently accepting waste. We
	performed tests of recoverability for eight of these landfills and during the year ended December 31, 2016, we recognized a $43&nbsp;million charge to impair one of these landfills in Western Pennsylvania due to a loss of expected volumes. For the
	other seven landfills, with an aggregate net recorded capitalized landfill asset cost of $281&nbsp;million, the undiscounted expected future cash flows resulting from our
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	probability-weighted
</FONT>
	estimation
	approach exceeded the carrying values. We did not perform recoverability tests for the remaining seven landfills as the net recorded capitalized landfill asset cost was immaterial.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Landfill Assets
</I>
	&#151; We capitalize various costs that we incur to prepare a landfill to accept waste. These costs generally include
	expenditures for land (including the landfill footprint and required landfill buffer property), permitting, excavation, liner material and installation, landfill leachate collection systems, landfill gas collection systems, environmental monitoring
	equipment for groundwater and landfill gas, directly related engineering, capitalized interest, and on-site road construction and other capital infrastructure costs. The cost basis of our landfill assets also includes estimates of future costs
	associated with landfill final capping, closure and
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	post-closure
</FONT>
	activities, which are discussed further below.

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	As of December 31, 2016, we estimate that we will spend approximately $400&nbsp;million in 2017, and
	approximately $900&nbsp;million in 2018 and 2019 combined, for the construction and development of our landfill assets. The specific timing of landfill capital spending is dependent on future events and spending estimates are subject to change due
	to fluctuations in landfill waste volumes, changes in environmental requirements and other factors impacting landfill operations.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Landfill and Environmental Remediation Liabilities
</I>
	&#151; As we accept waste at our landfills, we incur significant asset retirement
	obligations, which include liabilities associated with landfill final capping, closure and
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	post-closure
</FONT>
	activities. These liabilities are accounted for in accordance with authoritative guidance on accounting
	for asset retirement obligations and are discussed in Note 3 to the Consolidated Financial Statements. We also have liabilities for the remediation of properties that have incurred environmental damage, which generally was caused by operations or
	for damage caused by conditions that existed before we acquired operations or a site. We recognize environmental remediation liabilities when we determine that the liability is probable and the estimated cost for the likely remedy can be reasonably
	estimated.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	57
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage58"></A>

<P STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:8.0PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:2PT;MARGIN-LEFT:4%;BORDER-BOTTOM:1PX SOLID #000000; WIDTH:10%">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	(a)
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	Leachate management costs have increased because, in certain parts of the country, we are transporting leachate further in order to reach treatment facilities, the third-party fees charged for treatment of waste water
	have increased and the volume of leachate being disposed has increased.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Amortization of Landfill Airspace
</I>
	&#151;
	Amortization of landfill airspace, which is included as a component of &#147;Depreciation and amortization&#148; expense, includes the following:
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<B>
</B>
	the amortization of landfill capital costs, including (i)&nbsp;costs that have been incurred and capitalized and (ii)&nbsp;estimated future costs for landfill development and construction required to develop our
	landfills to their remaining permitted and expansion airspace; and
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<B>
</B>
	the amortization of asset retirement costs arising from landfill final capping, closure and
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	post-closure
</FONT>
	obligations, including (i)&nbsp;costs that have been incurred and
	capitalized and (ii)&nbsp;projected asset retirement costs.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Amortization expense is recorded on a units-of-consumption
	basis, applying cost as a rate per ton. The rate per ton is calculated by dividing each component of the amortizable basis of a landfill by the number of tons needed to fill the corresponding asset&#146;s airspace. Landfill capital costs and closure
	and post-closure asset retirement costs are generally incurred to support the operation of the landfill over its entire operating life and are, therefore, amortized on a per-ton basis using a landfill&#146;s total airspace capacity. Final capping
	asset retirement costs are related to a specific final capping event and are, therefore, amortized on a
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	per-ton
</FONT>
	basis using each discrete final capping event&#146;s estimated airspace capacity. Accordingly,
	each landfill has multiple
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	per-ton
</FONT>
	amortization rates.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The following table presents our landfill
	airspace amortization expense on a
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	per-ton
</FONT>
	basis for the years ended December 31:
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>

	58

<A NAME="eolPage59"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D252547D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D252547D10K_HTM_INDEX">
	Index to Financial Statements
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Different per-ton amortization rates are applied at each of our 248 landfills, and
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	per-ton
</FONT>
	amortization rates vary significantly from one landfill to another due to (i)&nbsp;inconsistencies that often exist in construction costs and provincial, state and local regulatory requirements for landfill
	development and landfill final capping, closure and
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	post-closure
</FONT>
	activities and (ii)&nbsp;differences in the cost basis of landfills that we develop versus those that we acquire. Accordingly, our landfill
	airspace amortization expense measured on a
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	per-ton
</FONT>
	basis can fluctuate due to changes in the mix of volumes we receive across the Company year-over-year.
</P>
</EFX_RESULTS_OF_OPERATIONS>
<EFX_LIQUIDITY_CAPITAL>
<A NAME="FIS_LIQUIDITY_CAPITAL"></A>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Liquidity and Capital Resources
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	We
	continually monitor our actual and forecasted cash flows, our liquidity and our capital resources, enabling us to plan for our present needs and fund unbudgeted business activities that may arise during the year as a result of changing business
	conditions or new opportunities. In addition to our working capital needs for the general and administrative costs of our ongoing operations, we have cash requirements for: (i)&nbsp;the construction and expansion of our landfills;
	(ii)&nbsp;additions to and maintenance of our trucking fleet and landfill equipment; (iii)&nbsp;construction, refurbishments and improvements at materials recovery facilities; (iv)&nbsp;the container and equipment needs of our operations;
	(v)&nbsp;final capping, closure and
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	post-closure
</FONT>
	activities at our landfills; (vi)&nbsp;the repayment of debt, payment of interest and discharging of other obligations and (vii)&nbsp;capital expenditures,
	acquisitions and investments in support of our strategic growth plans. We also are committed to providing our shareholders with a return on their investment through dividend payments and our common stock repurchase program.
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	We use long-term borrowings in addition to the cash we generate from operations as part of our overall
	financial strategy to support and grow our business. We primarily use senior notes and tax-exempt bonds to borrow on a long-term basis, but we also use other instruments and facilities, when appropriate. The components of our borrowings as of
	December 31, 2016 are described in Note 7 to the Consolidated Financial Statements.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Changes in our outstanding debt balances from
	December 31, 2015 to December 31, 2016 were primarily attributable to (i)&nbsp;net debt borrowings of $375&nbsp;million and (ii)&nbsp;the impacts of other
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-cash
</FONT>
	changes in our debt balances due to hedge
	accounting for interest rate swaps, foreign currency translation, discounts, premiums and deferred loan costs.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	As of December 31, 2016,
	the current portion of our
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	long-term
</FONT>
	debt balance of $417&nbsp;million includes (i) $230&nbsp;million of short-term borrowings under our long-term $2.25&nbsp;billion revolving credit facility and (ii)
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	59
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage60"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D252547D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D252547D10K_HTM_INDEX">
	Index to Financial Statements
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	$187&nbsp;million of other debt with scheduled maturities within the next 12 months, including $126&nbsp;million of tax-exempt bonds.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	As of December 31, 2016, we have classified $196&nbsp;million of borrowings outstanding under our $2.25&nbsp;billion revolving credit facility
	as long-term because we intend and have the ability to refinance or maintain these borrowings on a long-term basis. We generally use available cash to repay borrowings outstanding under our $2.25&nbsp;billion revolving credit facility and any
	remaining balances are maintained by extending the maturities of the borrowings. Our current projections indicate that we will maintain $196&nbsp;million of the $426&nbsp;million of borrowings outstanding for the next 12 months. The remaining
	$230&nbsp;million of borrowings outstanding under our $2.25&nbsp;billion revolving credit facility is classified as current in our Consolidated Balance Sheet at December 31, 2016.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	As of December 31, 2016, we also have $473&nbsp;million of tax-exempt bonds with term interest rate periods that expire within the next 12
	months and an additional $491&nbsp;million of variable-rate tax-exempt bonds that are supported by letters of credit. The interest rates on our variable-rate
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	tax-exempt
</FONT>
	bonds are generally reset on either a
	daily or weekly basis through a remarketing process. All recent tax-exempt bond remarketings have successfully placed Company bonds with investors at
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	market-driven
</FONT>
	rates and we currently expect future
	remarketings to be successful. However, if the remarketing agent is unable to remarket our bonds, the remarketing agent can put the bonds to us. In the event of a failed remarketing, we have the intent and ability to use availability under our
	$2.25&nbsp;billion revolving credit facility to fund the debt obligations until they can be remarketed successfully. Accordingly, we classified these borrowings as long-term in our Consolidated Balance Sheet at December 31, 2016.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	We have credit facilities in place to support our liquidity and financial assurance needs. The following table summarizes our outstanding
	letters of credit, categorized by type of facility at December 31 (in millions):
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>

	of letters of credit issued and supported by the facility, leaving an unused and available credit capacity of $1,035&nbsp;million.

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Net Cash Provided by Operating Activities
</I>
	&#151; The most significant items affecting the comparison of
	our operating cash flows in 2016 as compared to 2015 are summarized below:
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE=" MARGIN-TOP:0PT ; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT">
<I>
	Increase in earnings &#151;
</I>
	Our income from operations, excluding depreciation and amortization and asset
	impairments and unusual items, increased by $337&nbsp;million on a
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	year-over-year
</FONT>
	basis, principally driven
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	60
</P>

<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="8%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="TOP">
<P STYLE=" MARGIN-TOP:0PT ; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT">
	by earnings from our Traditional Solid Waste business. Our 2015 results included $51&nbsp;million of charges associated with the withdrawal from certain underfunded Multiemployer Pension Plans,
	of which payments of approximately $60&nbsp;million were made in 2015.
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<I>
	Cross-currency swaps
</I>
	&#151; During the first quarter of 2016, we terminated our cross-currency swaps associated with the anticipated cash flows of intercompany loans between WM Holdings and its wholly-owned
	Canadian subsidiaries, as discussed further in Note 8 to the Consolidated Financial Statements. In connection with the termination, we received cash proceeds of $67&nbsp;million, which were classified as a change in &#147;Other current assets&#148;
	and &#147;Other assets.&#148;
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<I>
	Decrease in annual incentive plan cash payments &#151;
</I>
	Payments for our annual incentive plans are typically made in the first quarter of the year based on prior year performance. Our cash flow from operating
	activities was favorably impacted by $46&nbsp;million on a
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	year-over-year
</FONT>
</FONT>
	basis, as the annual incentive cash payments made in 2016 were lower than the cash payments
	made in 2015.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">

	&nbsp;
</TD>

	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<I>
	Increase in income tax payments
</I>
	&#151; Cash paid for income taxes, net of excess tax benefits associated with equity-based transactions, was $36&nbsp;million higher on a year-over-year basis largely driven by
	higher pre-tax earnings in the current year.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">

	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<I>
	Changes in assets and liabilities, net of effects from business acquisitions and divestitures &#151;
</I>
	Our cash flows from operating activities were favorably impacted on a
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	year-over-year
</FONT>
	basis due to net changes in our assets and liabilities, exclusive of the items noted above, particularly non-trade related items including payroll and incentive accruals.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The most significant items affecting the comparison of our operating cash flows in 2015 as compared with 2014 are summarized below:
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<I>
	Increased earnings from our Traditional Solid Waste business &#151;
</I>
	In 2015, we saw an increase in earnings from our Traditional Solid Waste business, which was enhanced by acquisitions and corporate overhead
	cost reductions. These cash flow improvements were slightly offset by a decrease in earnings from our recycling operations.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">

	&nbsp;
</TD>

</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<I>
	Cash flow of divested businesses
</I>
	&#151; The divestiture of Wheelabrator in December 2014 coupled with the sale of other Solid Waste businesses throughout 2014 negatively affected the
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	year-over-year
</FONT>
</FONT>
	comparison by approximately $140&nbsp;million.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">

	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<I>
	Decrease in income tax payments
</I>
	&#151; Cash paid for income taxes, net of excess tax benefits associated with equity-based transactions, was approximately $329&nbsp;million lower on a
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	year-over-year
</FONT>
</FONT>
	basis, largely driven by (i)&nbsp;lower
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	year-over-year
</FONT>
</FONT>
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	pre-tax
</FONT>
	earnings primarily due to the loss on early extinguishment of debt in 2015 and (ii)&nbsp;the income tax implications and related impacts of divestitures and impairment charges.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
